Force parens around Ptyp_arrow type constraints on patterns with named (#2205)

args.

There's a bug in the grammar: the parser tries to parse tuples with named
arguments, resulting in an exception crashing refmt.

```reason
let testCallNamedArgs = (foo: (~a: int, ~b: int) => int), a, b) => foo;

(~a: int, ~b: int) => int /* interpreted as a Ptyp_tuple */
```

To unbreak master refmt, this patch forces parens around the Ptyp_arrow
constraint. With parens the correct ast is parsed.
```reason
let testCallNamedArgs = (foo: ((int, ~b: int) => int), a, b) => foo;
```

The parsing without parens will be addressed asap in a different PR.

they could have bugs in their code - but only if they overloaded ++ to
be something other than string concat, or where order matters.

[Reason] Cut Build Time In Half.

Summary:
1. One thing that contributors report as being a major point of friction
to contributing to the `Reason` repo is the long build times. This diff
ports the build to `jbuilder` which reduces the clean build times by
around 60%!  Incremental build time is also reduced by 50% when making
changes to the parser. I'm personally a lot more inclined to fix/improve
Reason when the build times are much faster.
This brings cold builds down from 24seconds to 11seconds
and incremental builds (when changing parser/printer) from 15seconds to
8seconds.

2. Since this uses `jbuilder`, it also allows easily removing the `utop`
dependency in the next diff. (I don't know how to refactor `ocamlbuild`
projects (`_tags`, `myocamlbuild`, wat.), but here, I just guessed how

* New jsx ppx tweaks

Accepts a command line flag. If it's `-version 2`, then use the new JSX
transform. If it's anything else, then:
  - use the old JSX transform
  - if the file has `[@@@bs.config {jsx: 2}]` at the top, use the new
    transform.

This makes sure nothing break when we upgrade everyone to the new
transform (used by rr2), *and* that when they start a new project, they
can put a `{"reason": {"react-jsx": 2}}` in `bsconfig.json` and have the
new transform without needing to put any config at the top of the files
(bsb will take care of invoking the ppx with the right flags depending
on bsconfig here).

We had a lot of hacks into rebuild so that we could statically link our
custom ocamlbuild rules into rebuild. It was a pain to maintain and debug.

Max and I found a less hacky approach to link the custom rules defined
in reasonbuild.ml:

1. Move reasonbuild.ml into a tmp directory, call it myocamlbuild.ml
2. Run ocamlbuild with '-just-plugin' option in that directory
3. Step 2 will generate a binary called "myocamlbuild", rename it and ship it
as "rebuild"

After step 3, 'rebuild' can now be used as an augmented 'ocamlbuild' with custom rules.

<JSX>   "Simplified" version of Sander's diff. (#775)

* [JSX] JSX: "Simplified" version of Sander's diff.

Summary: This is a version of Sander's JSX implementation which treats
JSX as "simple" constructs, meaning they are "clearly one unit", and do
not require parenthesis to be wrapped around them in order to be passed
as function arguments. That means you can treat <tag ...> as the
"opening paren" and "</tag>" as the closing paren.

This diff also supports:

   - Frags (which are simply lists that don't require commas separating
     contents).

   - Lists of JSX items

```
let myFunction =
   callSomeFunction
     <FirstItem>foo</FirstItem>
     <SecondItem>foo</SecondItem>;

let lst = [<Tag />, <AnotherTag />];

let lst =
  <>
    <Tag />
    <AnotherTag />
  </>;

```

Whats Not Implemented: Currently, the limitation of this approach is
that subsequent JSX elements must always have spaces separating them.
I have a good idea about how to solve that limitation, but we can start
using this right now, in an experimental mode.

```
let items = <Wrapper> <This /> <Must /> <Have /> <Spaces /> </Wrapper>
```

[Reason] Make Reason Idempotent Again

Summary:A previous diff had removed the idempotent nature of the pretty
printer, by taking

    let x =
      something; /* comment */

and formatting it like this

    let x =
      something /* comment */;

This is fine, if the outer semicolon having term does not begin on the
line, then "something" is the best candidate for having the end of
line comment attached to it. If that's the case, then it will jump
inside of the semicolon to indicate the association. (I think it's
actually a good thing to indicate what was inferred as the end of line
comment, and format accordingly). If we did not indicate this in the
formatting you'd be in for a surprise when joining several lines onto
one, and seeing how the meaning of the end of line comment has changed.
When we have the formatter give feedback about what the eol comment is
attached to, those surprises are eliminated.

The problem, is that before this diff, we were not clever enough to
continue to interpret the above example as an eol comment on
"something", because the semicolon would get in the way - making the
comment appear to not be an eol comment. This diff special cases
terminators such as ; and , so that they are ignored when attributing
the eol comment - we ignore trailing terminators. That necessitated a
large refactoring.

[AtomReason] Fix silent error from merlin (#321)

Slightly large diff that's mostly consolidating diff and making one
logical change. The problem was that before, each time we call merlin,
we register a listener (and immediately free it after a response). This
causes race conditions in `readline` where many concurrent listeners
(each one created by a merlin call) might read the same line.

The new implementation allocates only one (long-living) listener, at the
beginning, alongside the merlin process itself (thus the code
consolidation). It keeps a FIFO queue of `resolve`s so merlin calls will
be queued and answered to, in order. This is still asynchronous too.

This is a better version rebuild that doesn't rely on the hack which creates and removes
myocamlbuild.ml, thus supports parallel build.

How it works:
- A special rule is added to myocamlbuild.ml which bootstraps a binary called myocamlbuild
- The bootstraped binary is linked with our ocamlbuild rules (src/reasonbuild.ml) via reopt.sh to handle reason files
- In pkg/build.ml, the binary is installed as reasonbuild
- The script `rebuild` invokes reasonbuild directly to replace ocamlbuild
